speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about when you first started experiencing gait and limb ataxia? Was it sudden or did it develop gradually over time?

speaker: Patient
text: "I started noticing my balance wasn't quite right a few months ago, and at first, I thought it was just because I'd been standing for a long time. But as it got worse, I realized I wasn't the only one who was stumbling – my friends and family started commenting on my 'drunken' walk too. It's been getting progressively harder to walk normally."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you walk me through what your daily activities are like now? Do you have trouble performing tasks that require coordination, like tying your shoes or carrying groceries?

speaker: Patient
text: "I've noticed I have trouble with simple tasks like tying my shoes – I have to use both hands and take a few extra steps to make sure I'm stable. And when I'm carrying groceries, I feel like I'm going to lose my balance, so I have to take a more deliberate path to avoid stumbling. It's just become a part of my daily routine now."

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me more about any other symptoms you've been experiencing, such as balance issues, dizziness, or weakness in your arms or legs?



Doctor:

speaker: Patient
text: "I do get dizzy when I stand up from a seated position or change positions quickly, but I think it's just because my body's still getting used to the changes. And as for weakness, I'd say it's mainly in my right arm, especially when I'm lifting or carrying things. It's not super severe, but it's noticeable, especially when I'm doing tasks that require a lot of manual dexterity."

speaker: Doctor
text:
So, it seems like the ataxia started about 6 months ago, and it did develop gradually. Can you describe to me what you were doing around that time - were you involved in any activities that might have triggered or exacerbated the symptoms?



Also, I'd like to take a look at your shoes, if you don't mind. I'll just check your shoe-tying ability real quick to see how coordination is affected.

speaker: Patient
text: "I wasn't really involved in anything that I can think of that would have triggered it, but I did start taking a few dance classes about 3 months before I noticed the balance issues. I'm not sure if it's a coincidence, but I did have a bit of a fall during one of the classes, and I bruised my hip. Maybe that's a contributing factor?"

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me more about any recent changes in your sleep patterns or appetite - have you noticed any significant variations in either of these areas?



Also, please go ahead and show me your shoes, I'd like to observe your gait and how you tie your shoes.

speaker: Patient
text: "I've noticed I've been sleeping a bit more soundly lately, but I've also been having trouble falling asleep at night because my mind keeps racing about how I'm feeling. As for appetite, I've been eating a bit more, but I feel like I'm not really satisfying my hunger, and my food just doesn't seem to be sticking around. I've been having trouble with constipation, which isn't surprising, considering my Crohn disease, but it's still been a bit of a challenge."

speaker: Doctor
text:
I'd like to request a neurological examination, specifically a assessment of your deep tendon reflexes. Can you please stand up and lift your arms up towards the ceiling for me?



And, yes, please go ahead and show me your shoes. I'd like to observe your gait and how you tie your shoes.

speaker: Patient
text: "I'll stand up and lift my arms for you. Okay, I'm standing up now and lifting my arms up towards the ceiling. I'll hold them there for a second."

speaker: Doctor
text:
